title: China donates 480 million CFA to Independent Electoral Commission in Cote d'Ivoire
description: On 10 September 2015, the Chinese Ambassador officially donated office equipment worth 480 million CFA to Cote d'Ivoire's Independent Electoral Commission (Commission électorale indépendante or CEI) for the upcoming 2015 presidential election in October. The donation included 580 desktop computers, 580 laser printers, 20 laptops, 4 photocopiers, and 550 mobile phones.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates 480 million CFA to Independent Electoral Commission in Cote d'Ivoire

# Description
On 10 September 2015, the Chinese Ambassador officially donated office equipment worth 480 million CFA to Cote d'Ivoire's Independent Electoral Commission (Commission électorale indépendante or CEI) for the upcoming 2015 presidential election in October. The donation included 580 desktop computers, 580 laser printers, 20 laptops, 4 photocopiers, and 550 mobile phones.
justification: Project focuses on supporting electoral processes and governance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of office equipment to electoral commission, no energy or industrial components

title: China grants funds for Chicken Farm Project in Cote d'Ivoire
description: On 29 May 2015, the Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire signed an agreement granting unspecified funds for the establishment of chicken farms in Port-Bouët. This project is an opportunity for young Ivorians to learn entrepreneurial skills and promote small businesses. The project was co-financed by the Ivorian Government and a local NGO carried it out.   This project is part of the Sino-Africa People to People Friendship Action program (中非民间友好行动).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China grants funds for Chicken Farm Project in Cote d'Ivoire

# Description
On 29 May 2015, the Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire signed an agreement granting unspecified funds for the establishment of chicken farms in Port-Bouët. This project is an opportunity for young Ivorians to learn entrepreneurial skills and promote small businesses. The project was co-financed by the Ivorian Government and a local NGO carried it out.   This project is part of the Sino-Africa People to People Friendship Action program (中非民间友好行动).
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and entrepreneurship training without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Chicken farm establishment, focus on entrepreneurial skills and small business promotion, part of people-to-people friendship program

title: China Eximbank provides $601.9 million preferential buyer's credit for National Power Grid Upgrade Project (Linked to Project ID#59408 and #70270)
description: In September 2013, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire submitted a financing proposal to China Eximbank for the National Power Grid Upgrade Project. After years of negotiations, in December 2015, three different financing agreements for this project were signed:   (1) On December 7, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed a preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement [n° PBC (2015) No.21 Total No. (363)] worth $601,981,890.17 (CFA 346,320,149737.10) for the National Power Grid Upgrade Project (captured via Project ID#70267). The Ivorian Council of Ministers ratified this agreement on February 10, 2016.  (2) On December 16, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an RMB 1,105,039,777 (CFA 99,188,354,657.51) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [n° GCL (2015) No.19 Total No. (558)] for the National Power Grid Upgrade Project (captured via Project ID#70270). The Ivorian Council of Ministers ratified this agreement on February 10, 2016.  (3) On December 16, 2015, the Chinese Government issued a $35 million (CFA 21 billion) grant in support of this project (captured via Project ID#59408).   The China Eximbank loans and Chinese Government grant together financed 95.2% of the total project cost equal to $852.6 million (CFA 513.2 billion). The Government of Cote d'Ivoire agreed to directly finance the remaining $40.93 million (or CFA 24.6 billion), representing 4.8% of the total project cost.   According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China Eximbank made 9 loan disbursements through the GCL and the PBC (worth CFA 460,868,801,710.60) between 2016 and 2022: a CFA 72,323,780,816 disbursement on December 31, 2016, a CFA 128,908,276497 disbursement on December 31, 2017, a CFA 48,312,845,505 disbursement on December 31, 2018, a CFA 52,554,492,426 disbursement on April 30, 2019, a CFA 39,110,946,491 disbursement on October 31, 2019, a CFA 39,068,964,446 disbursement on December 31, 2010, a CFA 9,998,271,271 disbursement on March 31, 2021, a CFA 26,691,721,342.40 disbursement as of December 31, 2021, and a CFA 52,800,459,631 disbursement as of May 31, 2022.	   This project involves the construction of 946 kilometers of 225kV power transmission lines and 736 kilometers of 90kV power transmission lines, the installation of 13 new transformers, and the rehabilitation of 14 old transformers. More specifically, the project involves the construction of a 225 kV, 162 km transmission line that runs from Sérébou to Bondoukou, the construction of a 90 kV, 138 km transmission line that runs from Agnibilékro to Bondoukou via Tanda, the construction of a 90 kV, 170 km transmission line that runs from Bondoukou to Bouna, the construction of a 90 kV, 231 km transmission line that runs from Bouna to Kong, the construction of a 90 kV, 93.1 km transmission line that runs from Kong to Ferké, the construction of a 90 kV, 58 km transmission line that runs from Attakro to Daoukro, the construction of a 90 kV, 170 km transmission line that runs from Bouake 2 to Daoukro, the construction of a 90 kV, 57 km transmission line that runs from Daloa to Vavoua, the construction of a 90 kV, 54 km transmission line that runs from Zuénoula to Vavoua, the construction of a 90 kV, 66 km transmission line that runs from Seguela to Mankono, and the the construction of a 90 kV, 79 km transmission line that runs from Zuénoula to Mankono, the expansion of the Agnibilékro substation, the construction of 90kV substations at Tanda, Bouna, Vavoua, Mankono and Daoukro the construction of 225/90kV substations at Sérébou and Bondoukou, the construction of a 90/33kV substation at Kong, the doubling of a transmission line at the 225 kV Kossoubouake substation. The project will take place in four zones: Zone 1 in the North-east, Zone 2 in the Center-North, Zone 3 in the Center-West and Zone 4 in the West. The ultimate objective of the project is to provide electricity to 500 villages along the transmission lines.  China National Electric Engineering Co. (CNEEC) and China National Machinery Industry Corporation (SINOMACH) are the EPC contractors responsible for implementation. China Railway 25th Bureau and CMEC were also involved in implementation (most likely as subcontractors). The project is overseen by Société des Energies de Côte d’Ivoire (CI-ENERGIES), a state-owned asset holding company that is responsible for managing assets in the electricity sector. Project implementation commenced on December 28, 2016. However, a formal groundbreaking ceremony did not take place until July 7, 2018. The project was scheduled to take place over 43 months and end in July 2020. However, it was officially completed in May 2021.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Electricity Network Rehabilitation and Development Project. The Chinese project title is 国家电网改扩建 or 科特迪瓦电网项目 or 科特迪瓦国家电网发展和改造项目 or 科特迪瓦电网发展和改造项目. The French project title is Projet de réhabilitation et de développement du réseau électrique en Côte d'Ivoire or Réhabilitation du réseau électrique de Côte d'Ivoire or Projet de développement et de réhabilitation du réseau Electrique (PRODERCI) or Projet de réhabilitation et de développement du réseau électrique en Côte d'Ivoire (CNEEC)_N°19&21. 2. In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it identifies a single $776 million China Eximbank loan for this project. AidData records two separate loans: a GCL worth RMB 1,105,039,777 and a PBC worth $601,981,890.17. 3. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 1120071313516. The AMP project code is 725970301.

# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $601.9 million preferential buyer's credit for National Power Grid Upgrade Project (Linked to Project ID#59408 and #70270)

# Description
In September 2013, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire submitted a financing proposal to China Eximbank for the National Power Grid Upgrade Project. After years of negotiations, in December 2015, three different financing agreements for this project were signed:   (1) On December 7, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed a preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement [n° PBC (2015) No.21 Total No. (363)] worth $601,981,890.17 (CFA 346,320,149737.10) for the National Power Grid Upgrade Project (captured via Project ID#70267). The Ivorian Council of Ministers ratified this agreement on February 10, 2016.  (2) On December 16, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an RMB 1,105,039,777 (CFA 99,188,354,657.51) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [n° GCL (2015) No.19 Total No. (558)] for the National Power Grid Upgrade Project (captured via Project ID#70270). The Ivorian Council of Ministers ratified this agreement on February 10, 2016.  (3) On December 16, 2015, the Chinese Government issued a $35 million (CFA 21 billion) grant in support of this project (captured via Project ID#59408).   The China Eximbank loans and Chinese Government grant together financed 95.2% of the total project cost equal to $852.6 million (CFA 513.2 billion). The Government of Cote d'Ivoire agreed to directly finance the remaining $40.93 million (or CFA 24.6 billion), representing 4.8% of the total project cost.   According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China Eximbank made 9 loan disbursements through the GCL and the PBC (worth CFA 460,868,801,710.60) between 2016 and 2022: a CFA 72,323,780,816 disbursement on December 31, 2016, a CFA 128,908,276497 disbursement on December 31, 2017, a CFA 48,312,845,505 disbursement on December 31, 2018, a CFA 52,554,492,426 disbursement on April 30, 2019, a CFA 39,110,946,491 disbursement on October 31, 2019, a CFA 39,068,964,446 disbursement on December 31, 2010, a CFA 9,998,271,271 disbursement on March 31, 2021, a CFA 26,691,721,342.40 disbursement as of December 31, 2021, and a CFA 52,800,459,631 disbursement as of May 31, 2022.	   This project involves the construction of 946 kilometers of 225kV power transmission lines and 736 kilometers of 90kV power transmission lines, the installation of 13 new transformers, and the rehabilitation of 14 old transformers. More specifically, the project involves the construction of a 225 kV, 162 km transmission line that runs from Sérébou to Bondoukou, the construction of a 90 kV, 138 km transmission line that runs from Agnibilékro to Bondoukou via Tanda, the construction of a 90 kV, 170 km transmission line that runs from Bondoukou to Bouna, the construction of a 90 kV, 231 km transmission line that runs from Bouna to Kong, the construction of a 90 kV, 93.1 km transmission line that runs from Kong to Ferké, the construction of a 90 kV, 58 km transmission line that runs from Attakro to Daoukro, the construction of a 90 kV, 170 km transmission line that runs from Bouake 2 to Daoukro, the construction of a 90 kV, 57 km transmission line that runs from Daloa to Vavoua, the construction of a 90 kV, 54 km transmission line that runs from Zuénoula to Vavoua, the construction of a 90 kV, 66 km transmission line that runs from Seguela to Mankono, and the the construction of a 90 kV, 79 km transmission line that runs from Zuénoula to Mankono, the expansion of the Agnibilékro substation, the construction of 90kV substations at Tanda, Bouna, Vavoua, Mankono and Daoukro the construction of 225/90kV substations at Sérébou and Bondoukou, the construction of a 90/33kV substation at Kong, the doubling of a transmission line at the 225 kV Kossoubouake substation. The project will take place in four zones: Zone 1 in the North-east, Zone 2 in the Center-North, Zone 3 in the Center-West and Zone 4 in the West. The ultimate objective of the project is to provide electricity to 500 villages along the transmission lines.  China National Electric Engineering Co. (CNEEC) and China National Machinery Industry Corporation (SINOMACH) are the EPC contractors responsible for implementation. China Railway 25th Bureau and CMEC were also involved in implementation (most likely as subcontractors). The project is overseen by Société des Energies de Côte d’Ivoire (CI-ENERGIES), a state-owned asset holding company that is responsible for managing assets in the electricity sector. Project implementation commenced on December 28, 2016. However, a formal groundbreaking ceremony did not take place until July 7, 2018. The project was scheduled to take place over 43 months and end in July 2020. However, it was officially completed in May 2021.
justification: Project focuses on power grid upgrades and transmission infrastructure without specifying energy sources
evidence: Construction of 946km 225kV and 736km 90kV transmission lines, installation of transformers, grid expansion

title: Chinese Government provides $24.59 million USD grant for 29 MW Solar Power Project (linked to #69158)
description: On March 2, 2015, the Chinese and Cuban governments signed an Exchange of Letters for the implementation of solar power station projects. Cuba's Ministry of Energy and Mines planned to install photovoltaic facilities, capable of 29 MW in total, on five Cuban solar farms through a $24,590,000 USD grant and $22,950,000 USD soft loan, both provided by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). The loan element to this project is captured in linked project #69158.  The project management unit is China Qiyuan Engineering Design and Research Institute Co., Ltd., and the project general contractor is China Hydropower Engineering Consulting Group Company.  The first stage of this project involved the construction of two photovoltaic plants with a combined capacity of 9 MW.  The pair includes a 4 MW solar farm in the Pinar del Rio province and a 5-MW plant in Cienfuegos province, the latter being the largest facility of its kind in Cuba.  Construction of the power plants began on 18 November, 2016 and was completed and successfully passed technical acceptance on 12 April, 2018.  On 26 April 2018, the ceremony for the completion and handover of the photovoltaic power plants was held at the site of the 5MW project in Yagualama Town, Enfugos Province, Cuba. Solar parks will continue to be constructed in the Cienfuegos province until 2030. China will provide the technology while Cuba will take care of the physical construction.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 援古巴太阳能电站.2. Other sources have quoted the total capacity for this project as 21 MW (See: 2016/17 Knowledge Sharing Program (Industry & Trade) with Cuba and China entrega a Cuba dos parques de paneles solares para generar energías limpias).
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $24.59 million USD grant for 29 MW Solar Power Project (linked to #69158)

# Description
On March 2, 2015, the Chinese and Cuban governments signed an Exchange of Letters for the implementation of solar power station projects. Cuba's Ministry of Energy and Mines planned to install photovoltaic facilities, capable of 29 MW in total, on five Cuban solar farms through a $24,590,000 USD grant and $22,950,000 USD soft loan, both provided by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). The loan element to this project is captured in linked project #69158.  The project management unit is China Qiyuan Engineering Design and Research Institute Co., Ltd., and the project general contractor is China Hydropower Engineering Consulting Group Company.  The first stage of this project involved the construction of two photovoltaic plants with a combined capacity of 9 MW.  The pair includes a 4 MW solar farm in the Pinar del Rio province and a 5-MW plant in Cienfuegos province, the latter being the largest facility of its kind in Cuba.  Construction of the power plants began on 18 November, 2016 and was completed and successfully passed technical acceptance on 12 April, 2018.  On 26 April 2018, the ceremony for the completion and handover of the photovoltaic power plants was held at the site of the 5MW project in Yagualama Town, Enfugos Province, Cuba. Solar parks will continue to be constructed in the Cienfuegos province until 2030. China will provide the technology while Cuba will take care of the physical construction.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation through photovoltaic facilities
evidence: 29 MW solar power project, photovoltaic facilities, solar farms, renewable energy focus

title: China Eximbank provides $60 million preferential buyer’s credit for 20MW Jesus Rabi Biomass Power Plant Project
description: In May 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Cuba signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement worth $60 million for the 20MW Jesus Rabi Biomass Power Plant Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  The purpose of the project was to construct the 20 MW Jesus Rabi biomass power plant in the Matanzas province, north of the Jesus Rabi sugar plant.  The plant was expected to supply power to the daily production at the sugar plant, supply heat to the del Bardo brewery, and will sell the remaining power to national power alliances.  The project was initially discussed in June 2013, and construction was expected to begin by the end of that year; however, there appeared to be some difficulty in acquiring the promised $60 million from China Eximbank until 2015.  Shandong Electric Power Engineering Consulting Institute Corp., Ltd. (SDEPCI) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  It signed an EPC contract with AZCUBA (Cuba's state-run sugar monopoly).  The project entered implementation in March 2018.  As of July 7, 2020, the construction of the 20MW Jesus Rabi Biomass Power Plant Project was still ongoing.
staff_comments: 1.  The Chinese project title is 古巴郝苏斯拉比20MW生物质发电项目. 2. The Spanish project title is Proyecto planta eléctrica de biomasa Jesús Rabí.3. The name of the plant in Chinese is 古巴郝苏斯拉比生物质电厂项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $60 million preferential buyer’s credit for 20MW Jesus Rabi Biomass Power Plant Project

# Description
In May 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Cuba signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement worth $60 million for the 20MW Jesus Rabi Biomass Power Plant Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  The purpose of the project was to construct the 20 MW Jesus Rabi biomass power plant in the Matanzas province, north of the Jesus Rabi sugar plant.  The plant was expected to supply power to the daily production at the sugar plant, supply heat to the del Bardo brewery, and will sell the remaining power to national power alliances.  The project was initially discussed in June 2013, and construction was expected to begin by the end of that year; however, there appeared to be some difficulty in acquiring the promised $60 million from China Eximbank until 2015.  Shandong Electric Power Engineering Consulting Institute Corp., Ltd. (SDEPCI) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  It signed an EPC contract with AZCUBA (Cuba's state-run sugar monopoly).  The project entered implementation in March 2018.  As of July 7, 2020, the construction of the 20MW Jesus Rabi Biomass Power Plant Project was still ongoing.
justification: Primary purpose is biomass power generation, a renewable energy source
evidence: 20MW biomass power plant, using biomass from sugar plant, supplying power and heat to nearby facilities

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Water Supply System Improvement Project (linked to #64265)
description: On 30 October, 2015, the Chinese Government agreed to provide a grant to the Government of Cuba for the Water Supply System Improvement Project.  The grant proceeds were used to purchase equipment for the improvement of the water supply system.  This grant may be a part of a 36 million USD grant from the Chinese government to Cuba in 2018 (#64265) ; The value of the grant is unknown.  China General Technology was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  It delivered a batch of water supply equipment on 14 December, 2017.  The formal project handover ceremony for this project took place on 16 March, 2018.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 古巴供水系统改善项目.
combined_text:

title: Hanban funds construction of new Confucius Institute of Havana Building
description: On 14 October, 2015, the Confucius Institute of la Universidad de Habana inaugurated its new headquarters in el Barrio Chino of Havana (the Chinatown of Havana).  The new installation is a four-floor building called el Edificio Pacifico, for which the Confucius Institute Headquarters contributed 650,000 euro and the Cuban government contributed 5 million pesos.  This new headquarters comes as a result of a cooperation agreement with the Office of the International Council for the Chinese Language, which is also known as Hanban.  The inauguration was attended by Miguel Díaz-Canel, first vice president of the Council of State and Ministers of Cuba, Dr. Rodolfo Alarcón, minister of Higher Education, Zhang Tuo, Chinese ambassador to Cuba and Dr. Gustavo Cobreiro, rector of University of Havana.  The Confucius Institute was originally inaugurated on 30 November, 2009 in a small campus of the University of Havana. The building was opened 6 years after construction began.
combined_text:

On 14 October, 2015, the Confucius Institute of la Universidad de Habana inaugurated its new headquarters in el Barrio Chino of Havana (the Chinatown of Havana).  The new installation is a four-floor building called el Edificio Pacifico, for which the Confucius Institute Headquarters contributed 650,000 euro and the Cuban government contributed 5 million pesos.  This new headquarters comes as a result of a cooperation agreement with the Office of the International Council for the Chinese Language, which is also known as Hanban.  The inauguration was attended by Miguel Díaz-Canel, first vice president of the Council of State and Ministers of Cuba, Dr. Rodolfo Alarcón, minister of Higher Education, Zhang Tuo, Chinese ambassador to Cuba and Dr. Gustavo Cobreiro, rector of University of Havana. title: China Donates Equipment to Monitor Air Quality in Havana
description: On October 29, 2015, China donated high-technology equipment for the monitoring of air quality in different locations of Havana. This donation will contribute to environmental preservation and the health of the population. One of the planned stations is installed and is full-functioning in the headquarters of el Consejo de la Administración Municipal de San Miguel de Padrón, where representatives of China and Cuba signed the corresponding Certificate of Delivery. Fernando Mario González Bermúdez, first vice-minister of the Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología y Medio Ambiente (CITMA) and Wu Xiaquing, viceminister of China's Environmental Protection, signed the document. Wu Xiaquing, the vicetitular of China, said that this donation formed part of mutual scientific-technological collaboration projects. The exact worth of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

# Title
China Donates Equipment to Monitor Air Quality in Havana

# Description
On October 29, 2015, China donated high-technology equipment for the monitoring of air quality in different locations of Havana. This donation will contribute to environmental preservation and the health of the population. One of the planned stations is installed and is full-functioning in the headquarters of el Consejo de la Administración Municipal de San Miguel de Padrón, where representatives of China and Cuba signed the corresponding Certificate of Delivery. Fernando Mario González Bermúdez, first vice-minister of the Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología y Medio Ambiente (CITMA) and Wu Xiaquing, viceminister of China's Environmental Protection, signed the document. Wu Xiaquing, the vicetitular of China, said that this donation formed part of mutual scientific-technological collaboration projects. The exact worth of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on environmental monitoring equipment donation without direct energy transition impact
evidence: Air quality monitoring equipment donation, environmental preservation focus

title: Chinese Government provides $22.95 million USD loan for 29 MW Solar Power Project (linked to #54762)
description: On March 2, 2015, the Chinese and Cuban governments signed an Exchange of Letters for the implementation of solar power station projects. Cuba's Ministry of Energy and Mines planned to install photovoltaic facilities, capable of 29 MW in total, on five Cuban solar farms through a $24,590,000 grant and $22,950,000 soft loan, both provided by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). The grant is captured in linked project #54762.  The project management unit is China Qiyuan Engineering Design and Research Institute Co., Ltd., and the project general contractor is China Hydropower Engineering Consulting Group Company.  The first stage of this project involved the construction of two photovoltaic plants with a combined capacity of 9 MW.  The pair includes a 4 MW solar farm in the Pinar del Rio province and a 5 MW plant in Cienfuegos province, the latter being the largest facility of its kind in Cuba.  Construction of the power plants began on 18 November, 2016 and was completed and successfully passed technical acceptance on 12 April, 2018.  On 26 April, 2018, the ceremony for the completion and handover of the photovoltaic power plants was held at the site of the 5MW project in the town of Yaguaramas, Cienfuegos Province, Cuba. Solar parks will continue to be constructed in the Cienfuegos province until 2030. China will provide the technology while Cuba will take care of the physical construction.
staff_comments: 1. This project has been coded with Implementation status, as only 9 MW of the expected 29 MW has been completed. It is not known whether all of the solar projects being constructed in Cienfuegos are being financed by China but the ones that are already complete have had Chinese participation.2. The Chinese project title is 援古巴太阳能电站.3. Other sources have quoted the total capacity for this project as 21 MW (See: 2016/17 Knowledge Sharing Program (Industry & Trade) with Cuba and China entrega a Cuba dos parques de paneles solares para generar energías limpias).
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $22.95 million USD loan for 29 MW Solar Power Project (linked to #54762)

# Description
On March 2, 2015, the Chinese and Cuban governments signed an Exchange of Letters for the implementation of solar power station projects. Cuba's Ministry of Energy and Mines planned to install photovoltaic facilities, capable of 29 MW in total, on five Cuban solar farms through a $24,590,000 grant and $22,950,000 soft loan, both provided by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). The grant is captured in linked project #54762.  The project management unit is China Qiyuan Engineering Design and Research Institute Co., Ltd., and the project general contractor is China Hydropower Engineering Consulting Group Company.  The first stage of this project involved the construction of two photovoltaic plants with a combined capacity of 9 MW.  The pair includes a 4 MW solar farm in the Pinar del Rio province and a 5 MW plant in Cienfuegos province, the latter being the largest facility of its kind in Cuba.  Construction of the power plants began on 18 November, 2016 and was completed and successfully passed technical acceptance on 12 April, 2018.  On 26 April, 2018, the ceremony for the completion and handover of the photovoltaic power plants was held at the site of the 5MW project in the town of Yaguaramas, Cienfuegos Province, Cuba. Solar parks will continue to be constructed in the Cienfuegos province until 2030. China will provide the technology while Cuba will take care of the physical construction.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation through photovoltaic facilities
evidence: 29 MW solar power project, photovoltaic facilities, solar farms, renewable energy focus
